Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research Belmont Forum: VULnerability of Populations under Extreme Scenarios
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a six-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum. The Belmont Forum is a group of the world?s major and emerging funders of global environmental change research. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner organization provides funding for researchers from their country to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders. This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in a Collaborative Research Action, the six partner organizations have provided support for research projects that utilize a strong inter- and trans-disciplinary approach to examine climate, environmental, and related societal change in mountain regions. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in a consortium of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that brings together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).

This project seeks to use fossils, ancient and modern DNA samples from Morocco, Cameroon, South Africa, China, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia and Brazil, and modeling techniques to investigate how ecosystems in mountain ranges have changed over the past 21,000 years and to establish an index of vulnerability which can be used across different mountain ecosystems. This information will contribute to an understanding of how social and ecological changes may impact food security in these regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research our goal was to assess the resilience of mid-elevation Andean forests, often known as cloud forests, to climate change and human actions. We wanted to see if strong droughts that were known to have occurred in the last 10,000 years caused major disruptions of these systems. Our study area of the Andes fitted into a global collaboration in which teams were conducting similar assessments in the Atlantic forests of Brazil, China, Morocco and West Africa.

 

In the Andes, we found evidence of a series of decade-long droughts that could occur at almost any time, but which were most prevalent between 9000 and 4000 years ago. These droughts reduced humidity over the mountains leading to the lower limit of where ground-level clouds form moving further up the mountain. As that happened, we saw relatively minor changes in forest composition. The forests were maintained, but the balance of species was altered. In other words, the forests as an ecosystem were resilient to the changes that occurred.

 

Human impacts, however, created a different story. The first observed human impact was the introduction of fire to an ecosystem that did not burn naturally. Between 14,000 and 12,000 years ago the first humans enter this landscape, they set fires, and eliminated the ice-age megafauna, which included large herbivores such as giant ground sloth, elephant relatives and Glyptodons- armadillos the size of a Smart car. We cannot detect the changes in vegetation due solely to these extinctions as they co-occur with the first fires, and also the warming that ended the ice age. But between 14000 and 12000 years ago the High Andean grasslands were transformed, while the Andean forests were much less impacted.

 

Humans were slow to exploit the forested slopes, where they were wet, steep and inaccessible.  Contrastingly, valleys, and ridges running beside valleys, became the natural travel corridors connecting human populations in the highlands with the Amazon lowlands. Such areas were ecologically transformed and may be considered as manufactured landscapes. When drought influenced these regions, the effects were more profound, than on forests where people had not disturbed the landscape. Human actions were found to amplify the effects of climate change and reduce the resilience of the natural system.

 

We found people to be both opportunistic and adaptive in their use of landscape. During dry events they would clear areas of wet forest and pursue agriculture but retreat from those areas as climates became wetter. As lands became totally unsuitable for crop cultivation due to climate change, they may have been re-purposed as sacred settings, as was the case at Lake Condores, where a wet valley was allowed to redevelop forest opposite mortuaries set in the cliffs overhanging the lake. The view available to the ancestors was an important part of the burial practice.

 

We have produced a predictive model that provides probabilities for where people did and did not modify the forest prior to European arrival. We hope that this resource will help guide future archaeological, ecological and paleoecological research in this understudied region.
